titleStmt.title: THE
Merchant's Vindication of
CALLICOEs. Or, A Modest Answer to a
late PROLOGUE and EPILOGUE.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Fæmineo Generi tribuantur.
THE Muses whom the richest Silks array,
Refuse to fling their shining Gowns away;
The Pencil cloaths the Nine in bright Brocades,
And gives each Colour to the Pictur'd Maids,
Far above Mortal Dress the Sisters shine,
Pride in their Indian-Robes────and must be fine.
And must Two Bards in Consort Rhyme and Huff,
And fret these Muses with their Play-House Stuff?The Play'r in Mimick Piety may storm,
Deplore the Combe, and bid her Heroes arm,
The Arbitrary M────b in Paultry Rage
May curse the Belles and Chinces of the Age,
Yet still the Artist-Worm her Silk shall share,
And spin her Thread of Life in Service of the Fair.The Cotten-Plant whom Satyr cannot blast,
Shall bloom the Favourite of these Realms and last,
Like Yours, ye Fair, her Fame from Censure grows
Prevails in Charms, and glares above her Foes,
Your injur'd Plant shall meet a loud Defence
And be the Emblem of your Innocence.Some Bard perhaps whose Landlord was a Weaver
Pen'd the low Prologue to return a Favour,
Some Neighbour Wit that wou'd be in the Vogue
Work'd with his Friend, and wove the Epilogue.
Who Weavs the Chaplet, or provides the Bays,
For such Wool-gathering Soneteers as these?Hence then ye Home-spun Witlings, that persuade
Miss Chloe to the Fashion of her Maid,
Shall the Wide Hoop, that STANDARD of the Town,
Thus act subservient to a Poplin Gown?
Who'd smell of Wool all over? 'Tis enough
The Under-Petticoat be made of Stuff.
Lord! to be wrapt in Flannin just in May,
When the Fields dress'd in Flow'rs appear so gay────
──Shan't Miss be Flower'd as well as they?In what weak Colours wou'd the PLAD appear
Work'd to a Quilt, or study'd in a Chair?
The Skin that vies with Silk, who'd fret with Stuff?
Or who cou'd bear in Red a Thing so rough,
Ye knowing Fair how eminent that Bed
Where the Chince-Diamonds with the Silken-Thread!
Where Rustling Curtains call the Curious Eye
And boast the Streaks and Paintings of the Sky,
Of Flocks they'd have your Milky Ticking full
And all this for the Benefit of Wooll.But where, say they, shall we bestow these Weavers
That spread our Streets, and are such Piteous Cravers.
The Silk-Worms (brittle Beings) prone to Fate
Demands their Care to make their Webbs complete;
These may they tend, their Promises receive,
We cannot pay too much for what they give.M40121D5
